video.title: Learn JavaScript - Full Course for Beginners
video.description:
This complete 134-part JavaScript tutorial for beginners will teach you everything you need to know to get started with the JavaScript programming language.

⭐️Curriculum⭐️
This is a stand-alone video but it follows the JavaScript curriculum at freecodecamp.org. Access the curriculum here:
🔗 Basic JavaScript: https://learn.freecodecamp.org/javascript-algorithms-and-data-structures/basic-javascript
🔗 ES6 JavaScript: https://learn.freecodecamp.org/javascript-algorithms-and-data-structures/es6

⭐️Code⭐️
This course was created using scrimba.com. Access the course there along with the code:
🔗 Basic JavaScript: https://scrimba.com/playlist/pny4ghw
🔗 ES6 JavaScript: https://scrimba.com/playlist/p7v3gCd

🐦🐦 Follow course creator Beau Carnes on Twitter: https://www.twitter.com/BeauCarnes

⭐️Course Contents⭐️
0:00:00 Introduction
0:01:24 Running JavaScript
0:04:23 Comment Your Code
0:05:56 Declare Variables
0:06:15 Storing Values with the Assignment Operator
0:11:31 Initializing Variables with the Assignment Operator
0:11:58 Uninitialized Variables
0:12:40 Case Sensitivity in Variables
0:14:05 Basic Math
0:15:30 Increment and Decrement
0:16:22 Decimal Numbers
0:16:48 Multiply Two Decimals
0:17:18 Divide Decimals
0:17:33 Finding a Remainder
0:18:22 Augmented Math Operations
0:21:19 Declare String Variables
0:22:01 Escaping Literal Quotes
0:23:44 Quoting Strings with Single Quotes
0:25:18 Escape Sequences
0:26:46 Plus Operator
0:27:49 Plus Equals Operator
0:29:01 Constructing Strings with Variables
0:30:14 Appending Variables to Strings
0:31:11 Length of a String
0:32:01 Bracket Notation
0:33:27 Understand String Immutability
0:34:23 Find the Nth Character
0:36:28 Word Blanks
0:40:44 Arrays
0:41:43 Nest Arrays
0:42:33 Access Array Data
0:43:34 Modify Array Data
0:44:48 Access Multi-Dimensional Arrays
0:46:30 push()
0:47:29 pop()
0:48:33 shift()
0:49:23 unshift()
0:50:36 Shopping List
0:51:41 Write Reusable with Functions
0:53:41 Arguments
0:55:43 Global Scope
0:59:31 Local Scope
1:00:46 Global vs Local Scope in Functions
1:02:40 Return a Value from a Function
1:03:55 Undefined Value returned
1:04:52 Assignment with a Returned Value
1:05:52 Stand in Line
1:08:41 Boolean Values
1:09:24 If Statements
1:11:51 Equality Operators
1:19:17 And / Or Operators
1:21:37 Else Statements
1:22:27 Else If Statements
1:23:30 Logical Order in If Else Statements
1:24:45 Chaining If Else Statements
1:27:45 Golf Code
1:32:15 Switch Statements
1:41:11 Returning Boolean Values from Functions
1:42:20 Return Early Pattern for Functions
1:43:38 Counting Cards
1:49:11 Build Objects
1:50:46 Dot Notation
1:51:33 Bracket Notation
1:52:47 Variables
1:53:34 Updating Object Properties
1:54:30 Add New Properties to Object
1:55:19 Delete Properties from Object
1:55:54 Objects for Lookups
1:57:43 Testing Objects for Properties
1:59:15 Manipulating Complex Objects
2:01:00 Nested Objects
2:01:53 Nested Arrays
2:03:06 Record Collection
2:10:15 While Loops
2:11:35 For Loops
2:13:56 Odd Numbers With a For Loop
2:15:28 Count Backwards With a For Loop
2:17:08 Iterate Through an Array with a For Loop
2:19:43 Nesting For Loops
2:22:45 Do...While Loops
2:24:12 Profile Lookup
2:28:18 Random Fractions and Whole Numbers
2:31:46 parseInt Function
2:33:29 Ternary Operator

2:41:32 const Keyword

topLevelComment.author: JasonRobards2
topLevelComment.text:
The course takes a weird and strong difficulty jump around the beginning of the last half hour. From explaining each usage example of 'greater than' and 'smaller than' (separately), incremental increasing of even numbers and incremental increasing to odd numbers (separately) to arrow functions, nested arrow functions and functions feeding into other functions (using functions up until then never used).

I also feel that the examples used in the video could be more clear. For example, sometimes the example in the demonstration does not use the most simple use case. A solution would be to provide a more simplified use case first. From the demonstrated use cases is also is not always clear how they the code. Consistency in showing 'how it was done previously' and then writing the new code underneath could provide more clarity.

Furthermore, the speaker only sometimes shows the end result of the code. Often, he explains what the code does, without showing the log results. I feel the examples would be more clear when this was done with consistency.

replies.author: JasonRobards2

topLevelComment.author: frank F
topLevelComment.text:
I have a question.  about 15 minutes into the video you were dealing with increments and decrease you talked about using myVar-- or myVar++ as a substitute for typing myVar=myVar-1. my confusion is this what if you have Var my var=87: and you wanted to subtract or add a number greater than 1, will you use the same myVar++ or myVar-- or will it be myVar+++?

 I did scroll down to see if it's being asked before but didn't see it and with over 7,000 comments its possible it's there somewhere. you all are awesome btw! keep up the good work!!!

replies.author: Pipit Gusmayanti
replies.text: Use myVar += n (short for myVar = myVar + n) or myVar -= n (short for myVar = myVar - n)

replies.author: Amal Sunil
replies.text:
​@basira eslamiyeh Hey, I have just skimmed through this one.. looks beginner friendly. It's name is "JavaScript Programming - Full Course" by freeCodeCamp itself which is approx 8 hrs long.

You could also checkout w3schools for js related code examples with explanation.
(I'm not providing direct links cuz youtube sometimes filters out comments with links attached)

Btw no one(no single source) will ever teach you everything, just keep searching for the topics you want to get a deeper look into.

All the best my friend.
Cheers!

replies.author: basira eslamiyeh
replies.text: @Amal Sunil Thanks a lot! Do you have ant advice about any in depth course that is free. Thank you so much

replies.author: Amal Sunil
replies.text:
Hey, that's absolutely normal... btw I wouldn't advice you use a crash course as source of learning coding especially when you're a beginner.
Search for in depth course, that'll make you understand the fundamentals of programming(if you're learning JS then search of a JS course that's atleast 6-8 hours and beginner friendly).

When you're starting out, focus on the logic(how variables, functions, loops, conditions etc... work). The way you write it(syntax) is something you can google and find out later if you're not sure.

And you'll never be able to stop learning... even the most experienced programmers learn something new everyday and revise concepts.

topLevelComment.author: Clave Sounds
topLevelComment.text: Thanks so much for the tutorials. I'm a bit confused about why you put the id's in as strings, yet when you put the argument in the function you used number, and when console returned it listed them as numbers not strings. What's happening here?

replies.author: Pipit Gusmayanti
replies.text:
*Why you put the ids in as strings, yet when you put the argument in the function you used number*
Object keys can only be string or symbol (used for unique key).
When accessing property of an object, the key is converted to string, that means (for integer) object[5439] is the same as object['5439'].

*When console returned it listed them as numbers not strings*
Different consoles have different ways of formatting output, and the console used in the video just happens to format object keys without question mark if it's a number.

replies.author: Pipit Gusmayanti
replies.text:
Your first code is the same as in the video except the name of parameter is different, AVERAGE_TEMPERATURES inside the function points to the parameter of the function, not the variable declared outside the function.

In your second code, the function doesn't take any argument and AVERAGE_TEMPERATURES inside the function always points to the variable declared outside the function.

In your third code, you're destructuring a string that doesn't have property named "tomorrow"

replies.author: Pipit Gusmayanti
replies.text:
*myObj.checkProp* returns the value of a property named *"checkProp"* of object *myObj,* which doesn't exist.

*myObj[checkProp]* returns the value of a property with name that matches the value of *checkProp*

replies.author: Pipit Gusmayanti
replies.text:
The pattern is called *Immediately Invoked Function Expression (IIFE)*
The main purpose of IIFE is to prevent names from leaking into the global namespace by putting it inside a function and calling the function. Although i think it's overkill to do IIFE at 2:55:40.

About the syntax:
(function() {}) creates an unnamed function. The outer parentheses makes the function declaration an expression, this is required because unnamed function must be an expression. This expression returns the function declared inside the parentheses. The last parentheses calls the function (parentheses after an expression is a function call).
Conceptually, what IIFE does is similar to this:
function main() {} _// any function name would work_
main();

Remainder oparator % means if you divide 11 by 3, you'll  get 3 as an answer but you’ll get the remainder of 2.

topLevelComment.author: Tjmac
topLevelComment.text: This is excellent, and even if you are familiar with other languages I recommend going through the basics, not just for syntax but for a few things that old school C / Basic / Pascal people such as myself find a bit different about javascript.  A note that if you are doing the freeCodeCamp tutorials, this syncs up almost perfectly until you get to recursion and then seems to deviate from the video. I'm guessing the video creator was thinking recursion is not a beginner topic but the tutorial Author wanted it in the first section.

replies.author: Louis Fortunato
replies.text: @Tjmac Thank you for pointing this out. I felt like I was following and understanding this tutorial thoroughly until this about this point, but now that I have the basics and some exposure I hope to soon be able to reconcile my confusion with further tutorials

replies.author: Floyd Dean
replies.text: @Tjmac Are you talking to me?

replies.author: Tjmac
replies.text: another note, the class and construct examples are horrible and anyone new could easily conflate what is what.  There is a trend to use the same label for local, global and properties, which makes it difficult for a student to distinguish what is what.  On top of that they log just the property instead of the entire object.  'carrot' is a string passed to the constructor local variable 'name'. which is then assigned to the newly created object (also called carrot) which is of class vegetable, which has the name property = 'carrot'. LOL!!!!

topLevelComment.author: Melkior Wiseman
topLevelComment.text:
I've watched to about 1/3rd of the way in so far, and I'm only a beginner with Javascript but I do have extensive experience in programming so here are my thoughts so far on learning JS.
Part of the problem with learning a language like Javascript (which seem to be closely based on the C programming language) is in how versatile it is.  In Javascript, it's possible to both assign a value to a variable and compare the result, all in the same operation, such as in: if (var=other) { ... }
In that case, the value in "other" is assigned to "var" and if "other" is non-zero, then the expression evaluates to TRUE so the commands inside the curly braces are done, but if "other" is zero then the commands are skipped.  This is why the == operator is required in order to say "compare these two instead of assigning one to the other."  I started out with BASIC in which you can't both assign and compare at the same time, which means that the single equals sign is contextual and can be either an assignment operator or a comparison operator.
In the BASIC version I started out with, variables had to be "typed" as either numeric or string, and if you wanted to treat a string of digits as a number, it had to be explicitly converted to a number first.  There was no automatic conversion as in Javascript, therefore no need for the === (strict comparison) operator, since all comparisons were strict.

Javascript is very "forgiving" in some areas such as variable typing, but this makes it more complicated in other areas since you as the programmer need to think carefully about exactly what you're telling the computer to do.
Most programming errors involve the programmer mistakenly telling the computer to do the wrong thing.  Most "debugging" involves finding out where the mistake was made and correcting it.

When something is "returned" in function, it stops the function. So there's no use of "else", because if the other "if" statements are false, it continues running the code and then stops on "return '10 or under'"
My explanation isn't really that good, but I hope you get an idea of it

topLevelComment.author: kishred bird
topLevelComment.text: It's my understanding that declaring a variable with let is essentially the same thing as using var but more current am I mistaken?  I was taught to know about var as a usable legacy declaration but to use the modern typings instead. Thoughts? I'm extremely new as in first week of learning and very excited about it.

replies.author: MD
replies.text:
Yes, "let" is more current than "var". 
Many people agree that using "let" is better than "var" since it's more modern and causes less problems with scoping (restricting variables inside statements and stuff). My opinion on this is that you should use "let" when you want variables to be current and "var" when making variables global, because some people use "let" even when making variables global. However, it's up to your choice

topLevelComment.author: TheTrue_DV
topLevelComment.text:
1:22:27

This is a poor example for the usage of Else If, since the result doesn't change at all.
In the given example, the function exits as soon as it hits the first "return", so you won't ever get to the next 'matched condition'.

To see the issue with the pre- if else statement, try replacing the 'Returns' with console.log() and passing in a value of less than 5. As you can see, the issue doesn't occur with the "If Else" since the "If Else" also exits out once the condition got hit the first time.

replies.author: Sean Patterson
replies.text:
To be fair, JavaScript is hardly the very first step into programming that most people take, HTML and CSS are, and if you're unable to set up a workspace and feel comfortable working with the necessary tools required to learn JS at that stage then perhaps the aforementioned shortcomings are, in-fact, not those of the lecturers as you suggest but rather those of yourself and other such student's...?
Just a thought... Also it would have been quicker to search "local dev setup" in YouTube than it did to write out your whole comment.

Think about what you're saying here:

You (a student) with no appreciable knowledge of the subject (hence the need to view the video) are asserting that qualified and experienced professionals in a field that you are fundamentally an infant in, DO NOT know what they are doing and that they should be taking directives and instructions from you.

Does that more or less some up your position here?

If you want help with setting up your local machine so as to best make use of these courses, just ask... People will help you voluntary, willingly and for free and you might even make a couple of friends along the way :D

Code Editor:
VS Code - Free(and well supported with updates and security features), customizable(you can change color schemes and other preferences to your liking), extensible(you can add extensions), you can also use Sublime Text (also free just fewer options for customization but still good) if you're new to development avoid VIM and ATOM they don't offer much in the way of help and they're kind of like old cult classics movies (rocky horror picture show) mostly kept alive because some stubborn diehards refuse to let them go.

Extensions: Live Server by Ritwick Dey - provides a live dev environment for continuous updates throughout development.

create an index.html file, a styles.css file and an app.js file to work in:
in the HTML file type "!" just the exclamation point and then wait a moment - Emmet the abbreviation service built-in to VS Code will then pop up with a list of possibilities and templates, just press enter on the first one, the single ! - It provides boilerplate HTML to make a visible page in a browser.

Link your styles.css in the head of your HTML document and your script tag in the footer (you can also load it in the head space if you wait for all DOM Content to be loaded first but this video does not cover that JS.

This will set you up entirely and you'll be ready to practice JS endlessly.

Just a quick note on asking questions:
Try and avoid being confrontational, argumentative, demeaning, inflammatory, rude, etc when asking any question, the slightest (and yes I do mean the VERY slightest) hint of any of the above will almost invariably result in your post being skipped over time and time again, regardless of how righteously correct you see your position to be, you will NOT get a useful response from any human being who feels they're being condescended to in any way, shape or form.

I'M NOT ON freeCodeCamp's payroll nor do I have any impact or influence on their decision making processes whatsoever, this is just my personal experience and relaying of information that has worked for me personally in the past, I hope you find what you're looking for.

replies.author: Marcelo LB12
replies.text:
I prefer this long type of course honestly. If you're serious and u genuinely want to become decent at Javascript, spending 3 hours is barely anything. 
This man legit teaches u everything u need to know in such a way that u can listen and do what he does at the same time. 

Unlike those other tutorials that are way shorter (so they can give it the title "Learn Javascript in ... minutes!) and once you're finished with them and u wanna start by yourself u feel like u've forgotten everything. 

My advice to the people that just started watching this tutorial: Take it easy, give it time, don't rush it. Take notes and do what he does so u don't forget it. A bit of experimenting further can't harm you either. It took me about a week before I finished the tutorial and I can tell u every bit of that was worth it!

topLevelComment.author: Max
topLevelComment.text:
Really love the entire Javascript course - very well done! Two things that could be improved:
1. It would be better if you could go a bit more into detail with certain topics. For example, if we look at 'Global Scope' 58:54, you explain how a function can be used. What is unclear to me is why we start function fun2 with 'var output ='' ' (thus, why the empty strings?) and why fun1 and fun2 are outside of the function. As a complete beginner with JavaScript this is all new to me, so it would have been nice if things like that were explained as well. 
2. Show console for visualization purposes

replies.author: Max
replies.text: I totally forgot about this comment. Now it's 7 months later and I understand it all. That said,  I still don't like this approach. It's like they are overcomplicating very basic topics. Definitely not the best way to start learning new concepts..

replies.author: Rahat Uddin Mohammad
replies.text:
You will need both when developing websites. Let me explain - 

HTML will be used to give a structure to your website. To place texts, images, links etc. 

CSS will be used to make things more beautiful. Styling texts, images, links etc. 

Java Script will be used to make things interactive. Programming what happens when someone clicks on an image etc.

replies.text:
NOTE: make sure you have node.js installed before doing this
solution:
- Go to "Tools" and click on "Build System" 
- Select "new build system and paste the code
- Save it as "JavaScript" :

The Code:
{
  "cmd": ["C:/Program Files/nodejs/node.exe", "$file"],
  "selector": "source.js"
}

once you have saved it go to Tools again and select Build System and you should see JavaScript, select it.

replies.author: Michael Vigato
replies.text:
Because before running the program, JavaScript scrolls the file and "hoists" variables, meaning it will recognize them as being used somewhere in the code, and initializes their value to "null". You can google "JavaScript hoisting" for more precise information 

This is valid for variables defined through the var keyboard, which is not super common anymore

replies.author: Michael Vigato
replies.text:
a += b is short for a = a + b 
Let's say a=1, b=3 
a+=b is short for a = a+b, so 
a= 1+3 = 4

If b was -3, you'd have 
a = 1+ (-3) = -2

replies.author: Wintur윈터
replies.text: @Yakup Ünsal yes you cant wait until you are done with this, but you should come back and review after you are done learning unless you are really good at retaining information.

replies.author: Yakup Ünsal
replies.text: @Wintur윈터 what if im already half way through this tutorial? Should I just start on HTML and CSS after this, then?

replies.author: Wintur윈터
replies.text: For web development you should learn html and CSS first. You should do projects with those two languages and then go to javascript. Javascript makes your webpages responsive. Also, people tend to learn full stack javascript for front end and back end. Since you want to do front end, learning javascript like this is better after you learn html and CSS. Theres no point in learning how to make a website responsive if you dont even know how to make a website.

replies.author: 1 minute JavaScript
replies.text: I'd say try and build a small project with JavaScript first. Programming is more like playing an instrument than learning math. Make sure you're able to use the language first before you move on to something else. If you want to learn web development then learning HTML & CSS next isn't a bad idea.

topLevelComment.author: Pushy
topLevelComment.text: 3:14:54  Why do we ever want to create a class within a method, effectively returning a class? Wouldn't you rather have the class OUTSIDE the scope of a method (aka NOT in a method) so you can just instantiate an object of that class whenever? What advantage or reason do you put the class within a function instead of in global scope?

replies.author: Pushy
replies.text: @1 minute JavaScript hmm if it's merely to demonstrate it can be done, then I guess it makes sense. I was thinking maybe there's some established reason or good practice reason for it

replies.author: 1 minute JavaScript
replies.text: It depends on the situation and what the person who was writing the code was thinking. I think in most cases this wouldn't be done, but I'm sure there is a contrived scenario where this would be done. Or even maybe a good scenario. I think it's more so to show people that it can be done.

topLevelComment.author: Jay Goyal
topLevelComment.text: I have a question, why would you use switch over if-else?

replies.author: tonyfremont
replies.text: @Jay Goyal none that I'm aware of anyway.  I'm a traditional C/assembly language embedded kinda guy trying to get comfortable with python and JavaScript.  I'm not a huge fan of all the object and class stuff, but it is what it is, so I need to adapt.  Switch/case statements really don't bother me.  In a compiled language, switch/case might be better optimized by the compiler, but I don't know that it would make enough difference to worry about it on modern hardware with an interpreted language.  I don't think many python/JavaScript coders are counting bytes and clock cycles to eek out that last bit of performance. ;)

replies.author: Jay Goyal
replies.text: @tonyfremont OK, So there is no particular advantage of switch statements..... I have a Python background so I am more comfortable with if-else statement😅

replies.author: tonyfremont
replies.text: Switch has some restrictions that might force you to use if/else, but generally is easier to understand when looking at someone else's code.  It's still mostly a personal preference/style kind of thing.

topLevelComment.author: Tr4c3 L355
topLevelComment.text: I need some clarification on var vs const. var = variable; const = constant => var != const. While both are declarations and value assignments, var and cons are different, no only on scope but also the way the interpreter interprets the assignments, the first one is mutable while the second isn't. Then why are you calling a const variable? The other point that called my attention on this vid, is the jumping on the code snips used as samples. If functions haven't been covered, why are you jumping to functions in the very beginning of the course? I have seen this in many courses, always repeating the same phrase, "we will cover it later". If it is a progressive learning, then, base the exercise on what it has been taught so far. Thank you for the vid, very refreshing!

replies.author: Gurleen Singh
replies.text:
null and undefined are both same in this situation.

On first-line you declared variable "a" but didn't assign any value to it. Which means "label a" has no assigned or defined value and is UNDEFINED.


You are making an output on line 3 of "a" and at that the time there was no value defined to it.
But. You did define or assigned the value to "a" but inline 4.
try outputting the value of "a" after line 4 and you will get a= 7

Difference b/w Null and Undefined.

Null is a value that means nothing or no-value. it literally means empty.
Whereas Undefined means that there is no definitive value for a.

replies.author: SSNUTHIN
replies.text:
My first coding I learned was C+ using visual basics in 10th grade and I swore I'd never touch a line of code again.  Now that I am almost 30 I am coding again and  much calmer. While I still get that hair raising discomfort and anxiety, understanding that feeling helped me move past it.

I'm going to take a guess and say that you are a creative person; you like to see and understand big pictures and systems as a whole. I'm guessing that because I am similar and get the same kind of repulsion to numbers and logic regardless of my personal competency to do the work.  

That discomfort and anxiety is a product of left right brain conflict and it's the same discomfort that people who are left brain dominant feel when you tell them 'you just do it' when explaining how to draw a picture or ride a bicycle. 

Scientists have verified over and over again using split-brain and intact brain patients to prove that we actually have two minds that process different kinds of information, one processes information linearly (a then b then c or 1 then 2 then 3, etc) and the other processes information *relatively* (this related to that, near related to far, etc). Depending on our temperament  we all favor one and in most people one of those brains is a big bully taking on task they shouldn't (the main culprit of drawing seeming like magic to the untrained). 

So when I feel that anxiety and confusion and repulsion, that weird itchy feeling going up my spine and arms, I know that my brains are being uncooperative. 

There is good news: 

First, coding gets easier to conceptualize as it gets more complex. There's a lot of basics to establish, but once you get past the tedium you can work almost purely  in relative terms that require little to no math or proofs on your part using Object Oriented programming.  

Second, putting coding aside, if you can push through that aversion and master switching between logic mode and relative mode you will be beyond capable of any artistic or scholastic pursuit you want. I wish I had a reference that went into detail about triggering logic mode, but I love the book 'Drawing with the Right Side of the Brain' as it's very informative as far as being able to switch in and out of right-brain mode.  

I wish you the best of luck and I hope you find satisfaction in your pursuits.

replies.author: SSNUTHIN
replies.text:
Hi there! The cc() is the way we call the function. So when you see the series of cc(2); cc(3); and so on, the data inside the parentheses is the input and cc() is the name of the function. 

 You can find it declared right below the "count" global variable all the way at the top of the text editor at the line "function cc(card)." I hope this answer is helpful to yourself or others who potentially have the same question. Happy coding!

topLevelComment.author: CJ
topLevelComment.text: I'm only like 15 mins in and already have so many questions. Why add/subtract etc. variables rather than just assign the sum right away? Also, why declare variables and then assign them three lines later, instead of just assigning them with the declaration? Wish you would explain these things. I appreciate the time and work you put into this but it won't be of much use to me if I don't understand why these things work the way they do.

replies.author: CJ
replies.text: @Aashish thanks so much for taking the time to explain

replies.author: Aashish
replies.text: It's our wish to assign variables. We can assign them right away or after 3-4 lines. It really depends on the program. You'll realise that eventually.

replies.author: Aashish
replies.text: You can't assign the sum right away if you don't know what to add/subtract. There might be instances where you need to take the inputs from user and then add them. That's when the variables are used. We take the input from user and add them. To take the input, we need variables! :)

Array.pop removes the last element in the array. 
In the code you are logging the array before changing it.
If you log the array again, after calling pop on it, you'll see the updated array.

Makes sense?

replies.author: SSNUTHIN
replies.text: It's an interesting quirk I have seen when you try to console.log a function, same in PHP using echo, but I have a theory: I'm pretty sure the reason it logs like that is for debugging purposes. It lets you know that there is no output defined to be displayed by that variable (i.e. no console.log or return value) and that variable stores a function.  It may seem unecessary as we are calling 1 or 2 functions at a time but when you have an object oriented programming code with 100s of functions with varying scopes to debug it may be just the hint you need to get your code running correctly.

replies.author: Plamen Rogachev
replies.text:
Depends, if you want to make a game JavaScript is not for you.
Now if you want to make a game without game engine i recomend using Python (i recomend not using vscode instead PyCharm and download pygame or pgzrun packege) or if you want to do it with game engine use Unity which works with C# or Unreal Engine which works with C++(Note Unity is better for begginers) example for games made with Unity is: cuphead, ori and the blind forest, heartstone, inside, Virtual-rickality, firewatch, subnautica, beat saber, getting over it, SUPERHOT etc. Games made with Unreal engine: Fortnite, ARK survival evolved, some final fantasy games, borderlands 3, dragon ball fighterZ, GEARS 5, Tetris effect, Street Fighter V, Hellblade etc.
But again Unity is better for begginers.
If you have other questions or if you ment something else just tag me and ask.
I hope i'm in help

No it won't JavaScript is used for websites and programs running in browser only. if you want to make a game JavaScript is not for you.
Now if you want to make a game without game engine i recomend using Python (i recomend not using vscode instead PyCharm and download pygame or pgzrun packege) or if you want to do it with game engine use Unity which works with C# or Unreal Engine which works with C++(Note Unity is better for begginers) example for games made with Unity is: cuphead, ori and the blind forest, heartstone, inside, Virtual-rickality, firewatch, subnautica, beat saber, getting over it, SUPERHOT etc. Games made with Unreal engine: Fortnite, ARK survival evolved, some final fantasy games, borderlands 3, dragon ball fighterZ, GEARS 5, Tetris effect, Street Fighter V, Hellblade etc.
But again Unity is better for begginers.
If you have other questions or if you ment something else just tag me and ask.
I hope i'm in help

topLevelComment.author: Lil Scotchy
topLevelComment.text: I don't get how "else if" statements are more advantageous than simply another "if" statement.

replies.author: I I
replies.text:
It's much more efficient as it is less resource intensive, eg:

Numerous If statements:

If --------- Then
----------
End If
If --------- Then
----------
End If
If --------- Then
----------
End If





Numerous Else If statements:

If --------- Then
----------
Else If ---------- Then
----------
Else If ---------- Then
----------
End If.

As you can see in the top example there are numerous end if statements, whereas in the bottom there is only one. Each of the If statements are separate so even if the condition of the first statement is met, they are all checked. Since the else if statements are connected to the if statement, if an if or else if statement meets the condition it does not check the other statements. 

(Apologies if this was on the rambling side, I'm not the best at explaining things).

replies.author: Jack3dU
replies.text:
hasOwnProperty is a defined method than can be used in the function to check for certain data. 

So in this case, we are essentially checking whatever the value we pass in as (checkProp) appears in myObj. If it does, we return it hence myObj[checkProp] in line 11 but if not we return "Not found"

Make sense?

topLevelComment.author: Matt W
topLevelComment.text: Can someone explain why @3:05:05 the const half = (function...)(); is wrapped in a parenthesis and ends in empty parenthesis?

replies.author: Matt W
replies.text: but why the second () after the destructuring?

replies.author: Matt W
replies.text:
Notes: The parentheses ( ... ) around the assignment statement are required when using object literal destructuring assignment without a declaration.

{a, b} = {a: 1, b: 2} is not valid stand-alone syntax, as the {a, b} on the left-hand side is considered a block and not an object literal.

However, ({a, b} = {a: 1, b: 2}) is valid, as is const {a, b} = {a: 1, b: 2}

Your ( ... ) expression needs to be preceded by a semicolon or it may be used to execute a function on the previous line.

<!DOCTYPE html>

replies.author: Francis Lambert
replies.text: @Ck 2018 It runs in a script tag in your HTML file...it is embedded in the <body> tag. So it works the same way as HTML, except that it needs it's own file like HTML does. ex. filename.js will sit in <script src="filename.js"></script> that sits in the HTML BODY tag. Cool?

topLevelComment.author: Kirt Perez
topLevelComment.text: I feel like as this video goes on, the instructor loses the consistency in this video. If you are not using this video as a refresher course, its going to be a hard watch. In his "objects" section, he explains what an object is, but doesn't mention that it can also be called a key. At the end of the objects section, with the coding challenge, he uses the term key. The little things are what's making this video a bit confusing at times. It may or may not throw absolute beginners off. Just gotta be really conscious of each word this guy says. This is also not to say that this name calling is that important, but if you were to branch off to other resources, just be prepared to be loose with some of the terms you learn here.

topLevelComment.author: Daggen
topLevelComment.text: I am an js pro dev and this is bare bones, or about 1/10-th of the knowledge you have tu learn in order to make anything valuable. JS concept is different than most languages. There is a lot of different concepts in js, a lot of different modules, each with it's own rules and syntax. Some concepts are quite advanced to learn like functional programming. Then there are front end frameworks like Angilar and Vue and back  end ones like Node, you have to learn them too. Then no-sql dbases etc. Then there are a lot of add ons on top of that etc. In short, it is one of the most advanced and powerful languages today. Be prepared to learn all the time. There is no end of it.

topLevelComment.author: Ricky Demetro
topLevelComment.text:
I've watched the segment beginning at 2:03:06 about 6 times already and I still can't understand it. 


Particularly the part where he sets the property equal to itself 
collection[id][prop] = collection[id][prop]


I just can't wrap my head around why it is necessary, or what it does even, yet I tried the code without it and it won't work. 


Can anyone explain? :)

replies.author: Ricky Demetro
replies.text: @Sam Your way makes much more sense to me. Thank you.

replies.author: Sam
replies.text:
He doesn't do this: collection[id][prop] = collection[id][prop]


He does this: collection[id][prop] = collection[id][prop] || []


He wants to initialise collection[id][prop] to an empty array only if it's falsey. In my opinion this isn't a particularly clear way of writing it.


I would write it like this:


if (typeof collection[id][prop] === 'undefined') {
  collection[id][prop] = []

}

Don't give up, just take it one step at a time and then repeat the parts where you're confused as many times as you can. To accelerate the process find other resources that talk about the same thing. Different people explain things from different angels, and I think that you'll find one who explains things in a way that just clicks for you.

replies.text: The cc function is called multiple times to simulate the real game, where you get the cards one by one and once you get all your cards, only then you can decide whether to bet or hold depending on your cards. Based upon this course, I think Beau's teaching is one of the best in world, you know why? 
Beau wastes no time with any small talk, everything he speaks out is relevant to the concept he is teaching through out the course. Then to make it stick and for your practice, he dishes out a working example. These small but effective examples are priceless. 
After going through the example you get to understand how the concept can be applied in a project. 
A maximum round of applause for Beau and everyone at freeCodeCamp!

topLevelComment.author: Steven Barnes
topLevelComment.text: Anyone watching this is 2019. Don't use the var keyword, use let or const, if your value is not going to change. Also use "use strict" written exactly like that, as the very first thing in your .js file. Make sure to include the quotation marks. Finally, don't declare a variable without using a let or const. a = 1; for example. let a = 1 is what you want to use. You actually want to minimise global variables and make good use of function scope. Hope that helps somebody.

replies.author: Jay
replies.text:
JavaScript gives us four methods to add or remove items from the beginning or end of arrays:

pop(): Remove an item from the end of an array
let cats = ['Bob', 'Willy', 'Mini'];

cats.pop(); // ['Bob', 'Willy']
pop() returns the removed item.

push(): Add items to the end of an array
let cats = ['Bob'];

cats.push('Willy'); // ['Bob', 'Willy']

cats.push('Puff', 'George'); // ['Bob', 'Willy', 'Puff', 'George']
push() returns the new array length.

shift(): Remove an item from the beginning of an array
let cats = ['Bob', 'Willy', 'Mini'];

cats.shift(); // ['Willy', 'Mini']
shift() returns the removed item.

unshift(): Add items to the beginning of an array
let cats = ['Bob'];

cats.unshift('Willy'); // ['Willy', 'Bob']

cats.unshift('Puff', 'George'); // ['Puff', 'George', 'Willy', 'Bob']
unshift() returns the new array length.

topLevelComment.author: qub
topLevelComment.text:
_NOTE:_ While I was writing this I was *not* finished with the video and thus had written this down since I don't (and still will not until the three-hour video has ended) know if he included this. Because I did not finish watching this, this may be incorrect because I do not know JavaScript completely. If I spot the part where he explains this, (if there is one) I will take this comment down, and I don't and yet find an error in my script, I will edit this. You may have already figured this all out already, but I'll list it in case. *You may now click "Read More."* 
-----
I am also very sorry if this is a bit too much to understand. I was coding a website right before this.
-----
Quick example (I'm pretty sure) of adding *added* strings together without the "+=" method:
var numOne = "First. " + "Second.";
var numTwo = "Third." + "Fourth."
var numThree = numOne + numTwo
console.log(numThree)


I'm pretty sure the console's response would be: "First. Second.Third. Fourth."
-----
Yes, I did notice there was no space between Second and Third. The reason for this is because neither the variable numOne nor variable numTwo has prevented this with a space. I also made the "added" bold because it may have been a bit hard to spot that. What I mean by "adding added" is that I have combined one variable with another, and combined that same variable with another combined variable.

replies.text: He is using Scrimba dot com like he said at the beginning of the video. I recommend starting there. If you want what you wrote in VSC to show up in safari you need to save the code you wrote in between two <script> elements on an html file and load that file in safari. You'll probably need to re-save the file in VSC and reload the page in safari after each change to see it's effect.

replies.author: Philip
replies.text: "If (something)" equals "if (something == true)". That's indeed the way it is and it's perfectly fine. Let's say it's Monday and somebody comes to you and says "if monday, I give you $100". What would you naturally think is going to happen? If you say you'd think you'd get 100 bucks now, there's your explanation.

topLevelComment.author: hektor6766
topLevelComment.text: Push is explained as far as adding an item to the end of an array, but at 2:11:xx, there is no explanation of what push is doing in the loop. Why is it needed for iteration if i++ is already in the function?

replies.author: hektor6766
replies.text: Ah! at 2:14:50, when iterating i+=2, that defines the iteration, but push is still needed for the running action through the array?

replies.author: freeCodeCamp.org
replies.text: `.push` is not needed for iteration. The reason `myArray.push` is in the loop is to demonstrate that you can push something to an array for each iteration in a loop. The new value of `i` is pushed to `myArray` for each iteration. You can see that after the loop completes, the array now equals [0, 1, 2, 3, 4].

replies.author: Brute
replies.text: @It'sYoBoiGucci Take this advice with a grain of salt. I only got a diploma and now just started a part time com sci degree  last year while working full time for 2 years now at a software company doing cloud related stuffs. Yes there are free resources online, yes you can learn all of these for free. You will definitely need to try much much harder than your peers who went to get a degree like @kim yoojin said. And it definitely helps you learn new stuffs in school, just depends on your attitude towards the curriculum. I'd recommend checking out chernoproject's video on University

replies.author: difflocktwo
replies.text:
@It'sYoBoiGucci Am talking about higher education too. Get a bachelor's and a master's at least. You can crank them both in 4 years total if you're motivated. 6 is more typical.

They don't teach you JavaScript or any other language in higher education. They teach you about physics and then they say ok I need a model of the orbital transfer. They don't care what language you use as long as your code is readable and you can explain it.

replies.author: It'sYoBoiGucci
replies.text: @difflocktwo Man i am talking about 4 years of bachelor education. I already passed high school but i dropped out from my college . I am now trying to learn on my own. I believe having skills matters than someone with a degree but no skills!!

replies.author: difflocktwo
replies.text:
Obviously any science or engineering degree is going to help you land a job in those fields. There is no JavaScript college, they don't even teach you languages in school, just concepts. You have to learn the languages on your own anyway. 

Go to school, study, get good and have fun

replies.author: Kim Yoojin
replies.text:
I should add that if you went to college or university 

You'd have to learn more math (algebra/calculus/discrete maths etc) 
It would not be necessary when learning any programming language but sometimes it does help understanding how "things" work 

Learning at any educational institution and learning from any "good and thoroughly explained" YouTube video is almost the same 

+ I learn more from these videos than in any lecture (sometimes)

topLevelComment.author: Jeffery Muter
topLevelComment.text: Oddly, the FCC course immediately begins teaching you the basics of the syntax, however it skips one of the most fundamental aspects of teaching an introductory course, which is explaining in any way 'why' you're learning what you are. Why is being able to scout how many characters that are in a string important?(current lesson) How is this applied? How common is its usage? None of that is explained. I understand this site was designed by and for programmers, and not teachers, unfortunately, it shows. Total respect and love for what you're doing and the site, but it shouldn't take me 10 hours of learning the basics to finally get to the place where I can begin to understand piecing together all these little chunks of info and how they work together to actually do anything significant.

replies.author: Davi Nonnenmacher
replies.text: It's a JS course, not a logic course. I think it's supposed to teach the syntax and "general flow" of the language, primarily...

replies.author: C4oUre
replies.text: i've kind of found this to be the case throughout a lot of their lessons. There's never really any explanation into "why" you're doing what you're doing. They tend to breeze through a lot of things without giving much explanation, and you find yourself in a situation, like at the Word Blanks excercise around @38:00, where they're throwing new things like functions at you without any previous explanation into what it actually is. You've definitely got to look into a lot of additional information while working through FCC.

replies.author: Ramon Vazquez
replies.text:
I can try. The variables passed in the function declaration are positional arguments and are merely placeholders for the actual values passed when the function is called.  Semantically, these placeholders should be as descriptive as possible but they can be called anything.

ie: 
function add (x, y) { return x + y }

will return the same as:
function add (number1, number2) { return number1 + number2 }

or even:
function add (spaghetti, meatballs) { return spaghetti + meatballs }

it doesn't matter what you call them the return value will be same because each function is adding the value of the first positional argument to the second in the function call.

What Bo is doing here is assigning a default value to one of his arguments. JavaScript allows us to keep this value in the function call by omitting its position and the function will run as if we passed its value. 

ie: 
function add (spaghetti=50, meatballs=4) { return spaghetti + meatballs } 

could be called like this:
add()

and the return value would be 54.

We could change one or all of these values in the function call to get a different result. 

ie:
function add (spaghetti=50, meatballs=4) { return spaghetti + meatballs } 
add(10)
would return 14

and

add(20, meatballs=5), 
which is the same as 
add(20, 5)
will both return 25;


Hope this helps. 
Be well.

topLevelComment.author: Godofga
topLevelComment.text:
33:40 For anyone that wants another solution to that problem:

var myStr = "Jello World"; //String
var fix = "H";//Character to be fixed
var pos = 0;//Position of the character
var finalStr = "";
for(let aux=0;aux<myStr.length;aux++)//Building a new string
{
  if(aux!=pos)//If the position isn't the one that I wanna change
    finalStr+=myStr[aux];//Repeat myStr character
  else
    finalStr= fix;//Put the modified char
}
console.log(finalStr);//Logging
